definitions.definition: to attract somebody or make somebody want to do or have something, even if they know it is wrong
definitions.sensetop: tempt somebodytempt somebody into (doing) somethingtempt somebody to do something

examples.text: I was tempted by the dessert menu.
Don't tempt thieves by leaving valuables clearly visible.
He was tempted into a life of crime.
I was tempted to take the day off.
Did you ever feel tempted to cheat?
I was almost tempted to strip off and plunge straight into the pool.
She was sorely tempted to tell him what she really thought.

definitions.definition: to persuade or try to persuade somebody to do something that you want them to do, for example by offering them something
definitions.sensetop: tempt somebody (into something/into doing something)tempt somebody to do something

examples.text: How can we tempt young people into engineering?
Nothing would tempt me to live here.

definitions.definition: to do something too confidently in a way that might mean that your good luck will come to an end

examples.text: She felt it would be tempting fate to try the difficult climb a second time.
It would be tempting fate to say that we will definitely win the game.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French tempter ‘to test’, from Latin temptare ‘handle, test, try’.
